pullrequest.title: Part 3: Better plugin registration and management

content.raw:
With the last few commits, we've reached very nearly 100% line coverage. I used `LCOV_EXCL_[START/STOP]` to ignore sanity check lines that we expect are impossible to reach, because testing for impossible lines doesn’t really make sense.

The only lines that aren't covered right now are related to a future feature which isn't fully implemented yet. I'd like to keep the partially-implemented feature in this PR, though, because it affects the footprint of the `ignition::plugin::Info` struct, so if we keep it partially implemented in this PR, then we can maintain API and ABI compatibility when the implementation is finished.
content.html:
With the last few commits, we've reached very nearly 100% line coverage. I used LCOV_EXCL_[START/STOP] to ignore sanity check lines that we expect are impossible to reach, because testing for impossible lines doesn’t really make sense.

The only lines that aren't covered right now are related to a future feature which isn't fully implemented yet. I'd like to keep the partially-implemented feature in this PR, though, because it affects the footprint of the ignition::plugin::Info struct, so if we keep it partially implemented in this PR, then we can maintain API and ABI compatibility when the implementation is finished.

content.html: this function receives a path, not a plugin name

pullrequest.title: Part 3: Better plugin registration and management

content.raw:
There may be some terminology confusion, because sometimes “plugin” refers to a dynamically loaded library, so the phrase “library name” could be confused with “plugin name”. In the `ign-plugin` lexicon “library” refers to a dynamically loaded library, while “plugin” refers to a class instance that may be retrieved from a dynamically loaded library.

In this particular case, I meant “library name” to mean the same as “path to a library”. But I see how that can be confusing, so I’ve updated this documentation to be more specific: 902acbe
content.html:
There may be some terminology confusion, because sometimes “plugin” refers to a dynamically loaded library, so the phrase “library name” could be confused with “plugin name”. In the ign-plugin lexicon “library” refers to a dynamically loaded library, while “plugin” refers to a class instance that may be retrieved from a dynamically loaded library.

In this particular case, I meant “library name” to mean the same as “path to a library”. But I see how that can be confusing, so I’ve updated this documentation to be more specific: 902acbe

pullrequest.title: Part 3: Better plugin registration and management

content.html: can you document which value is which since they are both void pointers? I assume one is a DL handle, but what's the other one?

pullrequest.title: Part 3: Better plugin registration and management

content.raw: looks like a map from `dlHandle*` to a weak_ptr to the dlHandle that gets its reference counter incremented when libraries are loaded?
content.html: looks like a map from dlHandle* to a weak_ptr to the dlHandle that gets its reference counter incremented when libraries are loaded?

pullrequest.title: Part 3: Better plugin registration and management

content.raw:
That's almost exactly correct. The reference counter of the `shared_ptr` gets incremented when plugin classes taken from the library are instantiated, and the library will be unloaded when that `shared_ptr` gets deleted \(i.e. if all plugin class instances from that library are deleted and the loader is either deleted or told to forget that library\).

I’ve expanded on the role of this member in comments here: 907125d

The short version is that the role of this map is to ensure that each Loader has a single authority on the reference counting of each library that it has loaded.
content.html:
That's almost exactly correct. The reference counter of the shared_ptr gets incremented when plugin classes taken from the library are instantiated, and the library will be unloaded when that shared_ptr gets deleted (i.e. if all plugin class instances from that library are deleted and the loader is either deleted or told to forget that library).

I’ve expanded on the role of this member in comments here: 907125d

The short version is that the role of this map is to ensure that each Loader has a single authority on the reference counting of each library that it has loaded.

pullrequest.title: Part 3: Better plugin registration and management

content.raw:
I think the idea there was that checking the result of `plugin->HasInterface<SetInterface>()`  was sufficient to confirm that we loaded an appropriate type of plugin, and checking for `GetInterface` isn’t entirely necessary.

Still, there's nothing wrong with also checking for `GetInterface` so :thumbsup:
content.html:
I think the idea there was that checking the result of plugin->HasInterface<SetInterface>() was sufficient to confirm that we loaded an appropriate type of plugin, and checking for GetInterface isn’t entirely necessary.

Still, there's nothing wrong with also checking for GetInterface so
